data.title: Prevent buggy packages from breaking other packages
data.body:
When a buggy package throws in an event handler, other packages subscribed to that event are not notified. We see this pretty regularly in Nuclide, where a Nuclide feature stops working because a user has installed a buggy third party package. Recently a user had a buggy package installed which threw on TextBuffer will-save preventing the user from saving their file which was particularly frustrating.

I think Atom should catch all exceptions thrown by installed packages, while still reporting the exception in some way. This should give a good balance between robustness and debugability.

I have a pull request coming (https://github.com/peterhal/event-kit/commit/83ac63055b76d5ec74e551dfea7ebb5e09e62b82) for event kit emit which should make this proposal concrete. Beyond events, I would also like to see a solution for other places where Atom calls 3rd party packages including package activation/deactivation.

data.title: Restore open files etc. from previous session
data.body: I am really missing that Atom doesn't restore the open files/tabs, expanded tree view structure etc. from the previous session once I re-open it. Would make my work much easier.

data.title: TextEditorPresenter spec is flaky
data.body:
https://janky.githubapp.com/2593440/output

```
>> TextEditorPresenter
>>   ::getState()
>>     .content
>>       .tiles
>>         [tileId].lines[lineId]
>>           .decorationClasses
>>             it adds decoration classes to the relevant line state objects, both initially and when decorations change
>>               timeout: timed out after 1000 msec waiting for presenter state to update
>>             it honors the 'onlyEmpty' option on line decorations
>>               Error: Leaking subscriptions for paths: /private/var/lib/jenkins/workspace/atom/spec/fixtures/sample.js
>>                 at ensureNoPathSubscriptions (/private/var/lib/jenkins/workspace/atom/spec/spec-helper.coffee:122:15)
>>                 at [object Object].<anonymous> (/private/var/lib/jenkins/workspace/atom/spec/spec-helper.coffee:115:3)
>>                 at doNTCallback0 (node.js:419:9)
>>                 at process._tickCallback (node.js:348:13)
```

data.title: Downloading the Windows installer with IE 11 loses the .exe extension
data.body:
Clicking on the big "Download Windows Installer" link on the homepage downloads from the link `https://atom.io/download/windows`. When this is finished, however, the file name is `AtomSetup` with no extension. Renaming the file to add an `.exe` allows it to be run.

This is on a fresh [modern.ie](https://dev.windows.com/en-us/microsoft-edge/tools/vms/) VM with Windows 7 and IE 11.

(Let me know if this isn't the right place to report website bugs — I didn't find a repository for the website with a tiny amount of searching)

data.title: Keymap win32.json collision
data.body:
With ccccc9657c7f9f6ecfb161da6a850b770348391d my keymap (Swedish) now have a collision which means I can't type backslash (\).

```
"atom-workspace atom-pane": {
  "ctrl-alt-=": "pane:increase-size",
  "ctrl-alt--": "pane:decrease-size"
},
```

The culsprit (ctrl-alt-= in the keymap) is unfortunately mapped/triggered by me pressing ctrl-alt-+ which _should_ produce backslash.

![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/1297882/11843343/6b3db878-a409-11e5-8c21-a24f7e1790de.png)

This should be true for german keyboards as well from what I can see.

I temporarily fixed this with

```
"atom-workspace atom-pane":
  "ctrl-alt-=": "unset!"
```

I believe the keymaps could benefit from some localization. E.g that the _tree-view:toggle_ is actually triggered by ctrl-§ on my keyboard and not what's written in the keymap (ctrl+).

data.title: Prompt before opening large files to avoid making the editor hang by mistake
data.body:
We know that atom hangs when opening big files (#979). Usually I don't intend to open big files, but sometimes I do because of using the CMD+T dialog too fast, so by mistake. Can we prevent this with a small action the user has to take before ? Given that the the user has to wait a while when the file is opened, I think that warning the user and prompting to open is a small request. Then your team can focus on improving performance without getting many users frustrated until then.

![atom_open_big_file](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/570771/11843199/7df7c7c0-a408-11e5-8a36-477638bbd884.png)

data.title: Add Atom to Open With context menu list in Windows Explorer
data.body:
This modifies the registry to include Atom in the context menu for the same file extensions for which it appears in the Open With context menu list in Finder on OS X.
#4893

data.title: Serialize language state for untitled buffers
data.body:
Fixes #9992.

Although we're adding a new parameter to the serialized state, this should be a 100% backwards-compatible change. :raised_hands: 

/cc: @atom/feedback

data.title: json parsing issues when default code page is changed (Windows 7)
data.body:
Registry key HKEY_CURRENT_USER\Software\Microsoft\Command Processor\Autorun on my machine is set to "chcp 1251".
Each network query (plugin searh, featured plugins list, etc..) causes an error:
Unexpected token �: ������� ������� ��������: 1251

Whenever I startup my CMD it writes: 
Microsoft Windows [Version 6.1.7601](c) Корпорация Майкрософт (Microsoft Corp.), 2009. Все права защищены.
Текущая кодовая страница: 1251

I think that the last line was unexpected somewhere in json porcessor.

You are welcome to ask me any additional info. 

UPD: deleting the key helped me to solve the problem, but it is just a workaround, I really need this key active. 

UPD2: I changed the key to "chcp 1251>NUL". It works fine now.

data.title: OS X "Open With" Finder context menu points to previous version after an update
data.body:
Just pressed the button to update Atom, which works great.

But noticed that if I right-click on a file in Finder and "Open With" -> "Atom", sometimes there will be multiple Atom entries, and sometimes the solitary entry will be for the old version.

Is there a way to thoroughly conceal old versions of Atom from OS X so the only default behaviour is to use the latest version of Atom (instead of old versions)?

data.title: OSX Atom Helper renderer type lock up with100% CPU utilization
data.body:
Over the past few weeks I've noticed every once in a while my atom will lock up.. I am usually caught off guard and am left unsure what action I did to cause it. Today I happened to narrow it down. I am not sure the best way to debug ATOM crashes, I tried to open developer tools and start CPU profiling but the profiler never responded once it was in the error state. XCode profiling was best I could think to give ya.

Steps:
1) Started atom with: `atom -d --safe -f -w`
2) Open any folder with a few files
3) Open at least 3 files (it may work with 2 didn't try)
4) Split pane on an open file
5) Make sure that file is open in both panes
6) Drag the file from the left pane into the right

Result:
Atom freezes, no output to console, no response from dev tools.

Expect:
Anything but crash. Maybe it just has two open copies? Not sure.

The process responsible was:
`/opt/homebrew-cask/Caskroom/atom/latest/Atom.app/Contents/Frameworks/Atom Helper.app/Contents/MacOS/Atom Helper --type=renderer --js-flags=--harmony --no-sandbox --lang=English --node-integration=true --enable-delegated-renderer --num-raster-threads=4 --gpu-rasterization-msaa-sample-count=8 --content-image-texture-target=3553 --video-image-texture-target=3553 --channel=23160.1.347038967`

Hopefully this may give some sort of lead into the issue:
![screen shot 2015-12-15 at 4 50 56 pm](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/180184/11827943/5d26df9c-a34d-11e5-968f-050a5e977d9b.png)

data.title: Do not handle package activation exceptions in test mode.
data.body: I've run into difficulty writing tests a few times when my package failed to activate but the test environment didn't have anything interesting in the console or test output indicating that's where it failed. In `package.coffee` we should just re-raise if we're in test mode rather than calling `::handleError`. I plan to do this today, just writing up this issue to remind myself when I switch contexts (or in case I never get to it!)

data.title: Copy empty .lproj dirs to fix `navigator.language` on OS X
data.body:
(Related: https://github.com/atom/electron/issues/2484)

In Atom 1.3.1, navigator.language is always set to "English" on Mac OS X, even if the user is using another language. This is particularly troublesome because English isn't even an appropriate value for that field. (It should be something like `en-US`). This PR is a copy of a change we made to nylas/N1 to fix this issue. It turns out the empty `.lproj` directories inside Electron must be copied for language detection to work in Chromium.

data.body:
[images.zip](https://github.com/atom/atom/files/63051/images.zip)
I opened 3 files.
I did not touch the first one but edited the 2nd and the 3rd files.
I then right clicked on the 1st tab and clicked on the close pane option.
Then dialog boxes popped saying that you did not save the other 2 files.
Close pane for each file should be separate right i.e close pane option for a tab should close only that tab.
The above attached folder has the sequence of 9 images showing the above explained behaviour.
This problem also came up in safe mode(i.e after creating an atom instance by running "atom --safe").

data.title: Weird issue with backwardsScanInBufferRange on first buffer line
data.body:
We've recently run into a weird issue with `TextEditor::backwardsScanInBufferRange` (see https://github.com/fcrespo82/atom-markdown-table-formatter/issues/23)

Consider this snippet:

``` javascript
atom.workspace.getActiveTextEditor().backwardsScanInBufferRange(/./g, atom.workspace.getActiveTextEditor().getBuffer().getRange(), function(m) { console.log(m); m.replace(m.matchText+m.matchText); });
```

This should, as far as I can gather, duplicate every character in current editor's buffer.

On a buffer with empty first line, it evidently does, i.e. buffer text like this

```

abcdefg
hijklmn
opqrstu
vwzyz
```

becomes

```

aabbccddeeffgg
hhiijjkkllmmnn
ooppqqrrssttuu
vvwwzzyyzz
```

Note empty first line.
This is expected.

What is unexpected is if we take the same buffer without empty first line, e.g.

```
abcdefg
hijklmn
opqrstu
vwzyz
```

then it becomes

```
aabbccddeeffggdhhiijjkkllmmnnhooppqqrrssttuulvvwwzzyyzz
ooppqqrrssttuu
vvwwzzyyzz
```

Note how it gobbled up newlines and introduced duplication.

You can use code snippet mentioned above in dev.console to test this.

This is really strange. Hope that someone can shed some light on this behavior.
Looks like a bug if you ask me.

data.title: Invisible split tabs when original pane is destroyed
data.body:
I found a bug related to tab splitting into new panes. What happen is that when I split unsaved buffers into new panes, then close the original pane, no more splitting seems to be possible. Not really sure how to describe the issue, so I report the exact steps to reproduce it.

**Reproduction steps**
1 - open Atom
2 - create three new untitled buffers and modify them so they're marked as unsaved
3 - split the third buffer right (it will create a new pane)
4 - drag the second buffer in the second pane, then split it down (another pane is created)
5 - close the first buffer without saving it
6 - split right the two remaining buffer, or just one of them

**Expected behaviour**
When splitting the remaining buffers, new panes should be created, containing a copy of the split buffer.

**Observed behaviour**
When splitting the remaining buffers, nothing happens. In the dev console is possible to see that the text editors in the workspace are created.
- I tried to split both tabs, then I closed them. In this case, the two panes stay alive, while the split buffers are not shown (gif 1).
- If I split just one of the two remaining tabs and then close both of them, all the split buffers are shown all at the same time (gif 2).

**Screenshots and gifs**
First case: both tabs are split.
![untitled](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/472900/11815101/1a750742-a342-11e5-91d7-30eb5d095f0c.gif)

Second case: only one tab is split.
![untitled2](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/472900/11815102/1a785a8c-a342-11e5-8570-eb742fbd08b0.gif)

**Atom version**: 1.3.1
**Environment**: OS X El Capitan 10.11.1 and Windows 10

**Additional information**
- Problem can be reproduced in safe mode: yes
- Problem started happening recently, didn't happen in an older version of Atom: no
- Problem can be reliably reproduced, doesn't happen randomly: yes

data.title: Atom hangs when opening 2 files with same basename on different panes
data.body:
Atom hangs when I open 2 files with same basename, such as `foo/index.js` and `bar/index.js`, on different panes.
It shows `Editor is not responding` dialog but `Keep Waiting` doesn't solve the problem.

**Reproduction Steps:**
1. Open `foo/xxx` file.
2. Move to other pane.
3. Open `bar/xxx` file.

It also hangs when creating new file from tree view.

**Expected behavior:**

Open `bar/xxx` file on the pane.

**Observed behavior:**

Hangs.

**Screenshots and GIFs**

![2015-12-15 17 05 50](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/1403842/11805328/2c280e1a-a34e-11e5-9366-b5f7ad8ccac7.png)

Here's a capture movie.
https://youtu.be/iuiGKC136OY

**Atom version:** 1.3.1
**OS and version:** OS X 10.10.5

**Installed packages:**

This is the result of `apm list`:
https://gist.github.com/fand/06d1780462609405b520

Anyway, the problem also happens on safe mode.

**Additional information:**
- Problem can be reproduced in safe mode: Yes
- Problem started happening recently, didn't happen in an older version of Atom: Yes
- Problem can be reliably reproduced, doesn't happen randomly: Yes
- Problem happens with all files and projects, not only some files or projects: Yes

I'm not sure but issue #10067 seems similar to this problem.

data.body: Is it possible to make blank space at the bottom of code (like in sublime text)? So I don't have to see the bottom of the screen when i'm writing.

data.title: :memo: Linkify all docs mentions of Promises
data.body: Applies to #10058

data.title: Atom freezes when saving over a file that is open in another tab
data.body:
Trying to save a new file (or save-as an existing file) over a file that is open in another Atom tab causes Atom to stop responding. Only occurs if the file being saved over is open in the same Atom window.

**Reproduction Steps:**
1. Open an existing file in Atom
2. Create a new file from within Atom (i.e. File > New File)
3. Save the new file, giving it the same name and location as the other file that is open (i.e. overwrite the other file)

**Expected behavior:**

Atom doesn't freeze and the file is saved. 

**Observed behavior:**

Atom freezes and the file is not saved :disappointed: 

**Atom version:** 1.3.1
**OS and version:** Arch Linux, reproduced on OS X 10.10 (with a fresh `.atom` folder)

**Installed packages:**

Reproduced with a clean `.atom`, so none.

**Additional information:**
- Problem can be reproduced in safe mode: Yes
- Problem started happening recently, didn't happen in an older version of Atom: Unsure
- Problem can be reliably reproduced, doesn't happen randomly: Yes
- Problem happens with all files and projects, not only some files or projects: Yes

data.title: Make it easier to quickly close a large number of tabs
data.body:
Have you ever noticed how you can close a large number of tabs very quickly in Chrome? This is because the width of the tab is held constant until the mouse leaves the tab area, so if I close a tab, the next tab moves to occupy the exact same space that the previous tab did, with the "x" in the same position, allowing me to quickly close a large number of tabs by simply clicking repeatedly in the same spot.

I've noticed while using Atom that I oftentimes want to quickly close a large number of tabs, which proves to be challenging given the current state of tab closing. Below are two options for how this could be improved.

**Option 1 (easier)**

Move the "x" to the same side tabs are floated. For me, tabs are floated left (this may be different for right-to-left languages, I don't know). For me, if the "x" was also on the left, then you could rapidly close tabs by clicking repeatedly in the same position, since the "x" of the next tab would occupy the same position as the "x" of the tab that was just closed. This seems like the obvious solution to me, but there may be other reasons that the "x" was placed on the right-hand side that I'm not aware of.

**Option 2 (more difficult)**

Leave the "x" where it is (on the right-hand side), but use Chrome's approach of keeping the tab size constant until the user moves the mouse out of the tab region. This would require a lot more code, but would allow you to keep the "x" on the right-hand side (if that is important for some reason).

data.title: Emit state update when model's scroll position is changed
data.body: Previously, manipulating the model's scroll position would not emit a presenter state update.
